text: (soft music)
- Hi, it's Andy Jassy.

I'm back here at re:Invent
today on Wednesday.
Yesterday, I shared some areas
that I thought were really exciting
with respect to launches.
We talked about Trainium2 chips
and Trainium2 instances.
We talked about our Aurora DSQL database
and we also talked about our new Amazon
Nova Frontier models.

Today I'm gonna talk about
three areas of launches
that particularly interest me

and that I think are gonna
be interesting for you.
I'm gonna start with storage,

and I think a lot of
times it's easy to forget
how core and integral storage is,
but we're continuing to innovate

in a really important way
for you around storage.
And let me give you an example.
In S3 today, which is our object store,
we have over a million data lakes.

And increasingly, as
companies are expanding

the amount of data they
have to do analytics and AI,
you're seeing companies store objects
in the Parquet format.
It's just easier query.
And then over time, what you're seeing
is that companies are using Iceberg
to extend the functionality
and capabilities of these Parquet files.
So it allows you to inserts and updates

and schema changes and
things of that sort.
It also integrates really well.
Iceberg integrates really well with,
with query engines, analytics engines.

However, if you're managing
these Iceberg tables,
it's a lot of work.

You actually have to, you
have to do table management,
you have to do data compaction,
you have to clean up the files,
you have to do access control,
and it just takes a lot of time.
So what the S3 team launched
is they launched a new bucket type in S3
called S3 tables.
And what it effectively does is it makes
Iceberg a first class primitive in S3.

So it does all the table
management for you,

all the cleaning up of files,
all the data compaction,

all the access control,
much, much easier for you.
And it actually makes your queries,

your table queries and
Iceberg three times faster
and 10 times more transactions per second.

So it's much better
performance versus managing
those Iceberg tables than your own.

So I think this is gonna
be very, very helpful

for our customers in
storage and in analytics.
Then the second area I was gonna talk

about was my excitement
about what we're doing
in Bedrock right now.
So for those of you don't know,

Bedrock is our service that
has the broadest selection

of leading third-party frontier
of large language models

and then has the best
collection of features
to make it easiest for you
to build great generative AI applications.

These are things like model
evaluation and guardrails

and integrating with RAG
and taking agentic actions.
And so Bedrock has a lot of traction
and especially at this early stage

of where people are building
generative AI applications,
where companies are still experimenting
with lots of different model types

and often multiple model
types in the same application
and multiple model sizes.
Bedrock being able to seamlessly allow you
to move back and forth between models
and sizes is very compelling.

And I think that's part of
why it has lot attraction.
So the Bedrock team has announced a number
of things over the last couple days.

First, we've had, for a
long time, anthropic models
and LAMA models and stability models
and Mistral models and Cohere and AI21.
We added today Poolside and Luma models
into Bedrock, both very popular,
very performant models,
as well as a new Bedrock Marketplace

for models where we've
added over a hundred
new models into the Bedrock Marketplace.

So you'll have, you already
have the leading selection
of models and leading models,

now you have even broader
selection of those models.

Second thing they added was a
feature called Distillation.

And so this feature allows
you to take the intelligence

of a larger model and to infuse
that into smaller models.

And that resulting
smaller model allows you
to have lower latency or lower cost.
Very useful.
Then the third thing that they added

that I think is exciting
is they added something
called prompt caching.
And so if you think about it,
let's say you're a law firm
and you have lawyers who are asking

the same questions, by and
large, over and over again,

whenever somebody asks
a question in a prompt,
the prompt then takes certain actions,
it generates different tokens

and that consumes a bunch
of compute and time.

And so what prompt
caching allows you to do
is it allows you to cache those questions

and those prompts so that
the next time they get asked,
all that processing is done already
and ready for you to use again,
saves you a lot of time and money.
And then they also added something called
Intelligent Prompt Routeing.
And so this is a great feature
for if you're gonna actually ask questions

and you don't really know
some of your questions

you ask a model, need
the most sophisticated,
largest version of that model.
But the problem is when you have to go
to that most sophisticated model,

the latency is higher
and the cost is higher.
So whenever you can have a smaller version
of that model be able to answer it,
you get better latency and cost.
So this feature in Bedrock,
this Intelligent Prompt Routing,

you set what your
thresholds are around price
and around accuracy,
and then we will automatically route
to the right model to optimize
for you on that combination.
And then the last feature
I'll mention that Bedrock added
is something called Automated Reasoning.

And so we've been using
Automated Reasoning
for a long time inside AWS

and it really uses
effectively logic and math

to be able to verify
that an answer is right.

So we do this a lot of times
for identity access control.

And so Bedrock now allows
you to list a bunch
of policies ar around your data
and your own knowledge bases.
And then Automated Reasoning makes sure
that when we're giving you the inference
and the answer that it actually is correct
and matches what's accurate
and in your policy on your knowledge base.
That's a pretty significant set
of new features for Bedrock,

which is already the most
performant inference machine.

Now, I think what's gonna
happen moving forward
is that just like in every application
you have compute and you have storage,
and you almost always have database
and usually use analytics.
And now increasingly AI,
what you're gonna see is that

every application is
gonna have generative AI
or inference in it.

And what you're gonna
want is you're gonna want

inference service that not
only has the broadest array
of models you can use,

but the broadest array of
features that allow you

to be accurate, to be fast,
and to be cost-effective
and to take work away from you
that you would've otherwise had to do.

And if you look at the
rolling thunder momentum

of what's being added to
Bedrock almost every month,
it is very compelling
and that's why I think people are using
it so much for inference.
Third area I'm gonna mention is around Q.
So Amazon Q is our AI-powered assistant
that is the most capable assistant
for software development
and for leveraging your own data.
And so one of the capabilities in Q

that I think people are
finding very compelling
is what we call Q transformation.

And so if you're a
developer, you know that one

of the most tedious
things that you have to do
is you often have to move from one version
of something to another.

Oftentimes for security,
sometimes for cost.
And nobody really likes to do that work.
It's very tedious.
And so an example inside Amazon
is we had to move from one version
of Java to the next version of the JDK
for security reasons and to be updated.

And we had tens of
thousands of those packages

that normally would take
us many, many months to do.

And instead, we use Q
to do the transformation
automatically for all those upgrades.

And we did tens of
thousands of those upgrades
and saved 4,500 developer years

and over $260 million
using Q transformation.

That's very compelling, that's
very practical use of AI.

And our customers were very
excited about this idea
and they said, "Could you please build
transformations of other things
that we know we have to transform
but we don't wanna spend the time doing?"
And so we just launched three of them.
The first is we have a lot of companies

that are interested in
moving from Windows to Linux
for cost reasons, for security reasons,
for flexibility reasons.
And so we've built a Q transformation

that makes it easy to
move from .net to Linux.

The second one that we just
announced is for people
that are trying to move from VMware
into native EC2 or the cloud.
And this is something that companies
have been steadily marching toward
for many years now.

And then with the change
in ownership of VMware

where the cost of VMware
has gone off by so much,

it's been a significant
catalyst for people
to move more quickly into the cloud.
And so we built a Q transformation

that lets you move from
VMware to EC2 instances.
That's very compelling.

And then the third Q transformation
that we just launched,

I think handles may be
the very most difficult

transformation that
companies need to make,

which is trying to move
from a old mainframe
into a cloud environment.

And with mainframes, you
know, people don't even know

where the data is or how
it's laid out anymore.
The people that created that
and know a lot about that mainframe often,

you know, don't work
at the company anymore.

And that process of
moving from a mainframe,
which we've helped a lot of customers do
historically takes several years.
And so we built a Q transformation
that basically dissects and pulls apart
that mainframe into the different pieces
and the documentation surrounding it.

So it's much easier to be
able to move from a mainframe

and now you'll be able
to move from a mainframe

to the cloud instead of
it taking 3, 4, 5 years,
you can count it in inside of a year
in terms of months.

So those are three very
powerful transformations.

They're gonna help
enterprises move from legacy

implementations into more
modernized implementations
and into the cloud more easily.
By the way, if you wanna do generative AI,

try doing generative AI in
conjunction with a mainframe,
it's nearly impossible to do so.
This will help enterprises take advantage
of this new technology.
So those are some areas I'm excited about,
and I'll see you tomorrow.
